results.title: The Black Hood Strikes
results.brief_description: Winner in the Middle Animation category. Priceless jewels were stolen from a rich family during their fancy ball. It’s the BLACK HOOD!’ Only the local private investigator can get to the bottom of this terrible crime and find the Black Hood before he flees the country and it’s too late. Will he stop him, will he survive, will he run out of fuel and who is the BLACK HOOD? So many questions, it’s a mystery.

results.title: Amazing Mums
results.brief_description: A Winner in the Junior Live Action category of Screen It 2016. Have you ever wondered how your mum fits so much into a day? Well so has Sarah! Join her as she tries to figure out the mystery that is her mums schedule and how she could possibly fit so much into one day… she might just find out more than she bargained for!

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 28]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film titled ‘Fragments of 1940’, contains several segments each with its own title and other smaller scenes. Kenneth’s views around the city and the Botanical Gardens as well as his own garden which often features in his films. We see good examples of signs of the era for shops and businesses such as a large wall sign for ‘Sidney Cooke’ printers: a business which later became CMI Fasteners Manufacturers of NZ. The ‘Our Garden’ segment shows the Rankine home garden where Kenneth captures the family circle enjoying themselves among the flowers, trees and gardening activities. There is a look at an Anzac Day parade and friends appear in military uniform - a reminder of the current war. There is also a segment showing daughter Bettye’s school sports day (uniforms indicate possible colleges, Genazzano and Vaucluse).

Selected highlights list:
00:00:11:00 title card ‘Fragments of 1940’ followed by sub-title, ‘Melbourne’ begins the footage with panoramic views around Melbourne, possibly taken from somewhere in Elizabeth St as smoke from industry can be seen on the horizon presumably to the west and buildings in Elizabeth feature later in the reel.

00:01:30:00 there is a view likely to be from Royal Parade looking down Elizabeth St including the Queen Victoria Market to the right of the screen at 00:00:00:00. Scenes following feature some examples of the trams and cars of the 1940’s era.

00:01:55:00 there is a dockside shot likely to be Port Melbourne. Footage shows Melbourne buildings in the CBD including the roof of the APA Tower in Collins St.

00:02:19:00 we see examples of Melbourne’s business signs of the time on various buildings including half a very recognisable Myer store sign as well as Flinders St Station facade at the end of the street.

00:02:37:00 title card ‘Botanical Gardens Melbourne’ appears beginning a segment of views around the Gardens.

00:03:35:00 the conservatory at the Botanical Gardens.

00:06:31:00 school girls participating in athletic sports in a park.

00:08:24:00 cricket teams take over the park while the school gives out the prizes for the day.

00:10:06:00 starts scenes at several beaches with members of the Rankine family and possibly friends. We see swimmers as well as beach strolling and the Rankines under a large umberella.

00:12:33:00 the Rankines return to a garden setting and house verandah, possibly situated in the Dandenongs.

00:13:09:00 title ‘Our Garden’ appears followed by sub-title ‘Come into our Garden’ which is filmed on glass looking through to a colourful garden and one of the Rankine family beckoning us in.

00:13:47:00 scenes of the women in the Rankine circle potting flowers.

00:14:50:00 ball games in the garden driveway.

00:15:11:00 an interesting shot of two of the Rankine women walking along the driveway, seemingly one to work (books and briefcase) and daughter Bettye to school (books in hand). Followed by shots of trees and flowers.

00:16:10:00 Mrs Rankine hosing the garden and Bettye prepared for tennis. More shots of shrubs and flowers.

00:17:17:00 Kenneth shows us a family member or friend in what appears to be her military uniform. Followed by Mrs Rankine cutting flowers.

00:17:40:00 members of the Rankine circle posing for the camera in the garden and the front steps of the house, showing its name, ‘Dunmore’. These shots include a wider circle than usual in Kenneth’s films and also show us a variety of the style of clothes of the day.

00:18:19:00 and indoor shot ends the reel where we see Bettye sitting and chatting to a friend in his military uniform.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is more whimsical in approach than the family based footage seen in other films, as reflected by the title ‘Open Road Open Sky’. In the opening scene we see Kenneth a fellow traveller wandering along country roads as well as shots of roads into the distance and the skies overhead. Further into the reel we see the Sherbrooke Forest, the ‘Burnham Beeches’ and ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’. There are shots of several animals such as emu and echidna as well as quite a bit of birdlife and Kenneth’s favourite shots of flowers and trees. The reel ends with Kenneth walking away from the forests and an end title shot.

Selected sequence list:

00:00:27:00 title ‘Open Road Open Sky’, Kenneth and a fellow traveller wandering along country roads.

00:01:00:00 large power poles along country roads, a few examples of country houses.

00:01:47:00 kangaroos and peacocks.

00:02:45:00 Kenneth walks along a road with his camera.

00:03:14:00 an emu, echidna and a wallaby come into view.

00:04:15:00 close up of Kenneth filming behind his camera followed by ‘Burnham Beeches’ mansion and estate in Sherbrooke Forest and the ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’.

00:06:31:00 birdlife inlcuding storks and lyrebirds.

00:07:44:00 Indigenous rider on horseback, waving at the camera whilst he rounds up horses, camels and Shetland ponies on grassland.

00:08:07:00 brolgas (filmed only from neck down only so difficult to be certain).

00:10:03:00 a quick shot of a woman behind the camera.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film introduces the third Wootton child. Of particular note are the examples of hand made and hand knitted clothing worn by the children.

Selected highlights list:
(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:14:00:00 introduction of a third child to the Wootton family, with the three children sitting in the garden on the outdoor cane chairs very typical of the era; the older two children are showing their growing confidence in front of the camera.

00:02:11:00 we see a shot of the family in formal clothes , typical of the ‘Sunday best’ way of dressing and posing for photographs at the time.

00:02:40:00 to 00:02:59:00 shows the now toddler’s first steps to confident running around the lawn.

Selected highlights list:
(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:14:00:00 introduction of a third child to the Wootton family, with the three children sitting in the garden on the outdoor cane chairs very typical of the era; the older two children are showing their growing confidence in front of the camera.

00:02:11:00 we see a shot of the family in formal clothes , typical of the ‘Sunday best’ way of dressing and posing for photographs at the time.

00:02:40:00 to 00:02:59:00 shows the now toddler’s first steps to confident running around the lawn.
description_for_label:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film introduces the third Wootton child. Of particular note are the examples of hand made and hand knitted clothing worn by the children.

Selected highlights list:
(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:14:00:00 introduction of a third child to the Wootton family, with the three children sitting in the garden on the outdoor cane chairs very typical of the era; the older two children are showing their growing confidence in front of the camera.

00:02:11:00 we see a shot of the family in formal clothes , typical of the ‘Sunday best’ way of dressing and posing for photographs at the time.

00:02:40:00 to 00:02:59:00 shows the now toddler’s first steps to confident running around the lawn.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 3 focuses on the day the Queen and Duke arrived in Melbourne, and consists mainly of short sections of footage, much of which is also seen in other Reels of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 3:

Opens with aerial view of motorcade at top of Bourke Street, Melbourne, (probably leaving Parliament House). At 00:00:11:00 footage switches to Essendon Airport, with officials and police arriving in car and on motorbikes: 00:00:31:00 Crowds are seen waiting for the Queen’s arrival. 00:00:41:00 Arrival of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks. 00:00:50:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:01:07:00 footage of crowds along streets from moving car. 00:01:12:00 Queen and Duke walking across tarmac at Essendon Airport. 00:01:20:00 photographers filming the crowds from a moving car. 00:01:24:00 back at Essendon Airport, assembled sailors. 00:01:30:00 close-ups of various officials at, and leaving, Airport. 00:02:25:00 Queen and Duke exiting aeroplane. 00:02:34:00 Queen and Duke reviewing assembled sailors. 00:02:55:00 Queen and Duke in car beginning to leave airport, crowds running to view car. 00:03:07:00 close-up of luggage. 00:03:10:00 staff exiting plane. 00:03:35:00 drive past Essendon Town Hall with crowds on balcony of Town Hall and lining streets. 00:04:00:00 Crowds in street. 00:04:11:00 Queen and Duke on dais, Mayor making a speech. 00:05:08:00 street scene (probably in Essendon), with large crowd in process of dispersing. 00:05:18:00 cars leaving Essendon Town Hall. 00:05:35:00 crowd on steps of State Parliament shot from moving car. 00:05:51:00 crowds behind barriers lining CBD streets. 00:06:12:00 close-up of Henry Bolte, then leader of the Opposition Victorian Liberal Party, on street outside Parliament House. 00:06:27:00 close-up of Queen and Duke getting into car. 00:06:54:00 close-up of people in crowd with spires of St Patrick’s Cathedral in background. 00:07:37:00 State Parliament building, assembled police. 00:07:41:00 people watching from the top of the Imperial Hotel (still extant on the corner Bourke and Spring Streets, Melbourne), and a “Molina’s” sign can be seen (indicating Melbourne’s famous Molina’s Cafe). 00:07:49:00 close-up of workman affixing red carpet to steps of State Parliament; as a stray dog wanders past. 00:07:54:00 Queen’s car approaching State Parliament, crowds outside Parliament building. 00:08:50:00 a man vacuums the red-carpet laid outside Parliament building. 00:09:35:00 Queen and Duke exiting their car outside State Parliament. 00:10:00:00 the Victorian parliamentary Mace and Black Rod are carried up the steps of State Parliament, with Queen and Duke following. 00:10:38:00 Mace and Black Rod are carried down the steps again.

as a stray dog wanders past. 00:07:54:00 Queen’s car approaching State Parliament, crowds outside Parliament building. 00:08:50:00 a man vacuums the red-carpet laid outside Parliament building. 00:09:35:00 Queen and Duke exiting their car outside State Parliament. 00:10:00:00 the Victorian parliamentary Mace and Black Rod are carried up the steps of State Parliament, with Queen and Duke following. 00:10:38:00 Mace and Black Rod are carried down the steps again.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 24 contains footage of the royal visit to Flemington, also seen in Reels 1, 9, and 10 of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 24:

Reel 24 contains footage of the royal visit to Flemington (also seen in Reels 1, 9, and 10 of this Collection). It opens with footage of the Queen and Duke arriving, followed by aerial shots of the horses, jockeys and course. 00:03:25:00 the Queen presenting the winners’ trophy begins. 00:05:50:00 footage of horses racing. 00:07:40:00 to 00:08:33:00 the footage action is in reverse (including Queen and official party, horses and jockeys in mounting yard and racing, and crowd scenes.)

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 23 contains footage of the children’s display at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (also seen in Reel 8).

Detailed Description Reel 23:

The whole Reel is devoted to footage of the children’s display at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (also seen in Reel 8, B2003230). 00:02:32:00 the Queen and Duke are seen getting out of car and walking across the grass, before the camera returns to the athletics, dancing, marching and costumes of the assembled children. There are also scenes of the children relaxing and playing games when not ‘performing’ on the MCG.
